Psychological mechanisms of effective cognitive-behavioral treatments for PTSD.

questionList.questionText: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to behavioral concerns.  The patient's teacher reports that, for the past 4 weeks, he has been "distant with peers and distracted."  On a few occasions, he was found sitting in the hallway after asking to use the restroom.  The patient has also had frequent stomachaches, resulting in 3 missed days of school in the past month.  His mother says he usually follows the rules but received detention a month ago for abruptly leaving the classroom when the new class pet, a snake, was introduced to the students.  She also states that although the patient has "never loved school," he was a good student and used to enjoy some subjects, such as math.  She has noticed no change of behavior when he is at home or with friends on weekends.  When seen alone, the patient says, "I don't like my class.  Can I be in a different one?"  He has no significant medical history.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Height and weight are tracking consistently at the 70th percentile.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This child's abrupt change in behavior, which is temporally associated with exposure to the new class pet (snake) a month ago (ie, leaving the classroom abruptly, becoming distant and distracted, subsequently avoiding school), with symptoms not observed outside of school, is concerning for a specific phobia.

Specific phobias are characterized by an intense fear of a particular object (eg, animal) or a particular experience (eg, flying in an airplane).  In the absence of the feared object or experience, performance and behavior are normal, as are this patient's lack of school issues prior to introduction of the class pet and normal behavior at home and on weekends.

First-line treatment of specific phobia is with exposure therapy, a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy that focuses on exposure to the feared object or experience in a graded fashion that helps extinguish the fear response.

(Choice A)  Teacher and parent rating scales are useful aids in diagnosing attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).  ADHD can present with distraction, as in this patient, but this is evident in multiple settings (eg, home, school, extracurricular activities), not only school.

(Choice C)  Interpersonal psychotherapy is useful for the treatment of depression or relational difficulties with teachers or peers.  There is no evidence of pervasive depression or difficulty with relational functioning in this patient, who has had no change in behavior at home or with his friends on weekends.

(Choice D)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are used in the treatment of pervasive disorders such as major depression, generalized anxiety, and social anxiety disorder.  These medications are not considered first-line treatment for specific phobia.

(Choice E)  Social skills training can help in managing behaviors that interfere with communication and relationships but would not effectively target the anxiety and avoidance behavior associated with specific phobia.

Educational objective:
Specific phobia is characterized by intense fear and avoidance behavior related to a specific object or experience.  It is best treated with exposure therapy, a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy that includes graded exposure to the feared object or experience.

questionList.title: Specific phobia

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for evaluation of moodiness and behavioral concerns over the past year.  Her mother says, "She always stays out past curfew.  I've already tried grounding her, but she doesn't seem to care.  When I ask her to do household chores, she gets extremely annoyed and slams her bedroom door in my face."  The patient is failing multiple classes at school and blames her grades on "boring teachers" and being unfairly penalized for handing in assignments late.  A few months ago, the patient was sent to the principal's office after refusing to put away her cell phone during a test.  When the principal said her phone would be confiscated, she started arguing and impulsively cursed at him, resulting in suspension from school.  Family history is significant for bipolar disorder in the patient's maternal aunt and depression in her sister.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  On mental status examination, the patient is irritable and sarcastic, frequently interrupting when her mother is speaking.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Oppositional defiant disorder

Diagnosis

Pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness for ≥6 months

  • Argues with adults, defies authority figures, refuses to follow rules
  • Deliberately annoys others
  • Blames others for own mistakes or misbehavior
  • Easily annoyed, angry, resentful, or vindictive
  • Not due to another mental disorder

Treatment

  • Parent management training
  • Psychotherapy (anger management, social skills training)
  • No pharmacotherapy for ODD but assess for comorbid ADHD & treat if present

ADHD = attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; ODD = oppositional defiant disorder.

This patient's pattern of defiance of rules and authority figures, irritable mood, and blaming failures on others is suggestive of oppositional defiant disorder (ODD).  For a diagnosis of ODD, the oppositional behaviors must be excessive compared to normative, age-appropriate behaviors and observed during interactions with individuals other than siblings.

ODD should also be differentiated from conduct disorder, which is characterized by more severe and aggressive behaviors (eg, physical aggression or cruelty toward people or animals, destruction of property, stealing, lying) (Choice C).  However, ODD can precede the development of conduct disorder, and it increases the risk of adult antisocial behavior, impaired impulse control, substance abuse, anxiety, and depression.

Treatment of ODD consists of management programs in which parents are trained to reward prosocial behavior and use brief, nonaversive consequences for misbehavior.  Individual or group psychotherapy focusing on anger management, problem-solving, and social skills is also beneficial.

(Choice A)  This patient's behavior represents a general pattern of oppositional behavior rather than a response to a specific psychosocial stressor.  In addition, adjustment disorder is not diagnosed when symptoms are better explained by a more specific disorder, such as ODD.

(Choice B)  A diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires distinct episodes of major depression and mania/hypomania, which are not seen in this patient.  This patient's moodiness is more likely related to annoyance at adult rules and demands.  Angry/irritable mood is a key feature of ODD.

(Choice D)  Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by failure to control aggressive impulses and presents with recurrent, physical, or verbal outbursts.  These patients do not display generalized moodiness, argumentative and intentionally defiant behavior, as in ODD.

(Choice E)  Although some adolescents may occasionally challenge rules and authority in the process of asserting their independence, this patient's behavior is persistent and impairing.  School suspension, significant academic dysfunction, and chronic parent-child communication/relationship concerns differentiate this patient's behavior from normal adolescent development.

Educational objective:
Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of argumentative and defiant behavior toward authority figures.  It does not involve the more severe violations of basic rights of others seen in conduct disorder.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Oppositional defiant disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Oppositional defiant disorder: current insight.
Common questions about oppositional defiant disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to behavioral problems at school.  The patient started at a new school 2 months ago after his family moved to the area for his father's job.  His teachers report that he is fidgety in the classroom and has difficulty completing assignments on time.  His mother states that he has always been a good student, but his grades have been declining over the past year, despite spending 3-4 hours on homework every night.  The patient states that assignments have been taking longer to complete because he must rewrite them until his handwriting is "just right."  He worries that if he does not achieve this, his father will lose his job and the family will have to move again.  The patient has had no change in sleep or appetite.  He does not feel sad or depressed but describes feeling anxious.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities, and results of routine laboratory evaluation are within normal range.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Clinical features

  • Obsessions
    • Recurrent, intrusive, anxiety-provoking thoughts, urges, or images
  • Compulsions
    • Response to obsessions with repeated behaviors or mental acts
    • Behaviors not connected realistically with preventing feared event
  • Time-consuming (>1 hr/day) or causing significant distress or impairment

Treatment

  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (exposure & response prevention)

This patient's time-consuming obsession with getting his handwriting "just right" and compulsive rewriting that is performed to prevent a feared event are consistent with obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).  OCD is a chronic condition that often begins in childhood or adolescence.  Patients frequently have high levels of chronic anxiety because they struggle to suppress distressing, intrusive obsessions.  Compulsions are intended to prevent a feared event from occurring and are usually not connected to the event in a realistic way (eg, the ability for handwriting appearance to prevent the father from losing his job).

First-line treatment for OCD includes selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and/or cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) based on exposure and response prevention.  The SSRIs fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, and sertraline have been shown to be safe and effective in the treatment of pediatric OCD.  CBT is the most effective form of psychotherapy and involves exposing patients to thoughts, images, and situations that make them anxious and preventing the accompanying compulsion.

(Choice A)  Buspirone is an antianxiety medication that is used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), which would not explain this patient's obsessions and compulsions.  OCD can be associated with chronic anxiety but is not necessarily accompanied by GAD.

(Choice B)  Dialectical behavior therapy focuses on treating emotional dysregulation and self-harm behaviors in borderline personality disorder (eg, unstable relationships, impulsivity).  It has no demonstrated efficacy for OCD.

(Choice D)  Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication used primarily in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.  This patient's fidgeting and difficulty completing assignments are likely due to his anxiety related to the intrusive obsessions and compulsions.  A stimulant would risk worsening his anxiety.

(Choice E)  CBT is the psychotherapy of choice for OCD.  Psychodynamic psychotherapy, which focuses on unconscious conflicts and developing insight, does not include the targeted behavioral exposure techniques aimed at decreasing compulsive behaviors.

(Choice F)  Reassurance and follow-up would not adequately address this patient's symptoms that are causing increasing distress and academic dysfunction.  OCD requires pharmacological treatment and/or structured psychotherapy with a CBT-trained therapist.

Educational objective:
First-line treatment of pediatric obsessive-compulsive disorder includes selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and/or cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Obsessive compulsive disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Obsessive-compulsive disorder in children and adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for acute onset of nausea and diarrhea.  By the time the patient is seen, the abdominal distress has resolved, but she remains agitated and is certain "there is something really wrong with me."  Over the past 2 months, the patient has had 4 similar episodes during which she experienced a sudden sinking feeling in her stomach, accompanied by nausea, sweating, rapid heart rate, and shortness of breath.  On 2 occasions, these symptoms were also accompanied by diarrhea.  She has become increasingly fearful of leaving her home and tearfully reports, "I am going to lose my job."  The patient works as a receptionist and has called in sick 5 times in the past 4 weeks because she fears having an episode at work.  She does not use illicit drugs.  Medical history is unremarkable.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 121/77 mm Hg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination is within normal limits and laboratory results are unremarkable.  While awaiting discharge, the patient suddenly feels nauseous again.  Her breath becomes shallow and rapid.  She sweats profusely and says, "My heart is pounding…going to die."  Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Panic disorder

Clinical
features

  • Recurrent & unexpected panic attacks with ≥4 of the following:
    • Chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, choking
    • Trembling, sweating, nausea, chills
    • Dizziness, paresthesia
    • Derealization, depersonalization
    • Fear of losing control or of dying
  • Worry about additional attacks, avoidance behavior

Treatment

  • First-line/maintenance: SSRI/SNRI &/or cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Acute distress: benzodiazepines

SNRI = serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

The presence of recurrent episodes of abdominal distress, diaphoresis, shortness of breath, racing heart, and severe anxiety in an otherwise healthy young adult with a negative medical workup is suggestive of panic disorder.  Panic disorder involves both panic attacks and persistent concern about additional attacks and/or a change in behavior to avoid having another attack.  Panic disorder may present with a wide array of physical symptoms, with some patients coming to the emergency department with fears that they may be very ill (eg, having a heart attack) or dying.

The long-term treatment of panic disorder may include antidepressants, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and/or cognitive-behavioral therapy; however, both interventions require weeks to take effect and would not alleviate this patient's immediate symptoms and marked distress (Choices B and C).  Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) can provide rapid relief of panic attacks and can also be used in the short term while waiting for an SSRI to take effect.  Due to the risks of misuse and addiction, they should be prescribed cautiously in patients with a history of a substance use disorder.

(Choice A)  Buspirone is an anxiolytic used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.  It is not effective in the management of acute anxiety and is not used to treat panic disorder.

(Choices E and F)  This patient's history of recurrent episodes of nausea that resolve spontaneously is consistent with panic attacks, and her physical examination and laboratory results do not point to an alternative explanation.  The proton pump inhibitor omeprazole may be used in the treatment of conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease.  Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist antiemetic that is used in patients with persistent nausea.

(Choice G)  The nonselective beta-blocker propranolol is sometimes used for performance anxiety but there is no evidence of benefit in panic attacks.

Educational objective:
Benzodiazepines provide rapid relief of anxiety and are indicated for the management of acutely symptomatic and functionally impaired patients with panic disorder.  Antidepressants and cognitive-behavioral therapy are preferred for long-term treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Panic disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnosis and management of generalized anxiety disorder and panic disorder in adults.
Pharmacological treatment of panic disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man comes to the office due to anxiety.  The patient was recently promoted at work, requiring a move from the 2nd to the 15th floor of his office building.  He says, "Every time I have to take the elevator to my new office, my heart starts pounding and I can't catch my breath.  I am having panic attacks on a daily basis."  The patient is distracted at work, spending at least an hour worrying about leaving the building.  At night he needs 2-3 hours to fall asleep due to worries about his work performance.  The patient has had similar episodes in the past and notes that he has been fearful of heights since adolescence, when he learned that his cousin suffered severe injuries from a fall.  He has no other medical or psychiatric history.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Specific phobia

History &
clinical features

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for >6 months
  • Common types: fear of flying, heights, animals, injections, blood
  • Avoidance behavior (eg, avoiding bridges & elevators, refusing work requiring travel)
  • Common (10% of population)
  • Usually develops in childhood, often after traumatic event

Treatment

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy with exposure (first-line)
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines (limited role, may help acutely if therapist unavailable or insufficient time)

This patient's fear of heights is consistent with the diagnosis of specific phobia, in which he fears a specific object or situation (phobic stimulus).  The first-line treatment for specific phobia is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which involves exposure to the phobic stimulus in a controlled setting.

Exposure is typically performed in a gradual manner (systematic desensitization), which results in decreased anxiety over time through habituation and extinction.  Although in vivo exposure is optimal, imaginal and virtual reality exposure are also effective and may be more feasible.  Exposure therapy has been shown to be superior to pharmacologic treatment in specific phobia.

(Choice A)  Pharmacotherapy is not a first-line treatment for specific phobia.  Medication (most commonly benzodiazepines [eg, alprazolam]) is appropriate when behavioral therapy is unavailable or the phobic stimulus is infrequently encountered.  The risks for dependence, rebound anxiety, and cognitive impairment when using benzodiazepines generally outweigh the benefits.

(Choice B)  Dialectical behavior therapy is useful for patients who struggle with emotion regulation and distress tolerance and is commonly used to treat borderline personality disorder.

(Choice D)  Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant used in the treatment of major depressive disorder.

(Choice E)  The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor sertraline is a first-line treatment for panic disorder and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), not specific phobia.  This patient does not have the spontaneous, unprovoked panic attacks required for the diagnosis of panic disorder.  His anxiety is specific to the repercussions of his phobia on his work performance and is not characteristic of the diffuse anxiety seen in GAD.

(Choice F)  Trauma-focused psychotherapy is a form of CBT used to treat posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).  This patient does not describe intrusive symptoms (eg, flashbacks, nightmares), pervasive hyperarousal, and negative thoughts related to his cousin's fall, which would be expected in PTSD.  His recent onset of anxiety in response to the phobic stimulus of riding the elevator is characteristic of specific phobia.

Educational objective:
Specific phobia is characterized by a marked fear of a specific object or situation.  Cognitive-behavioral therapy using exposure techniques is the preferred treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Specific phobia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Specific phobias.

Inferiority or even superiority of virtual reality exposure therapy in phobias?—A systematic review and quantitative meta-analysis on randomized controlled trials specifically comparing the efficacy of virtual reality exposure to gold standard in vivo exposure in agoraphobia, specific phobia, and social phobia.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office due to panic attacks.  She was promoted at work 7 months ago and has experienced severe anxiety, trembling, sweating, chest tightness, and shortness of breath when giving presentations or meeting new clients.  The patient says, "I have been anxious around people since I was a teenager, but it is getting worse.  It's very embarrassing.  I know everyone can see that I'm extremely nervous in meetings and will think I'm incompetent.  I'm afraid I'll make a fool of myself.  The last time I had to speak, I became so anxious that I couldn't breathe and almost passed out."  The patient is becoming increasingly concerned that she will lose her job, which is resulting in poor sleep.  She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine on weekends and does not use illicit substances.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  On mental status examination, she is visibly anxious throughout the interview and avoids eye contact with the physician.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 anxiety disorders

Social anxiety disorder
(social phobia)

Anxiety restricted to social & performance situations, fear of scrutiny & embarrassment

Panic disorder

Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks

Specific phobia

Excessive anxiety about a specific object or situation (phobic stimulus)

Generalized anxiety disorder

Chronic multiple worries, anxiety, tension

This patient's severe anxiety related to fears of negative evaluation and embarrassment in social and performance situations is consistent with social anxiety disorder (SAD).  Her history suggests that she has been socially anxious since adolescence and that the demands of her new job have exacerbated her condition.  Her persistent anxiety and poor eye contact during interaction with the physician are also characteristic of the disorder.  According to DSM-5, patients whose symptoms occur only in performance-related situations are specified as having the performance-only subtype of SAD.

SAD related to discrete performance situations may be mistaken for a specific phobia.  When fears are related to being publically scrutinized, embarrassed, or negatively judged in a social context (as in this patient), the appropriate diagnosis is SAD.  Having a specific phobia is characterized by the fear of a specific object or situation (eg, flying, heights, animals) rather than the fear of negative evaluation in a social situation (Choice E).

(Choice A)  Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by multiple, uncontrollable worries (eg, health, finances, relationships, family) whereas this patient's anxiety is restricted to fears of negative evaluation in social and performance situations and its potential consequences (eg, losing her job).

(Choice B)  SAD may present with panic symptoms triggered by a feared social situation.  However, to make a diagnosis of panic disorder, unexpected panic attacks are required with the fear related to the panic symptoms themselves.  This patient's panic symptoms are always triggered by a fear of embarrassment and humiliation in social and performance situations.

(Choice D) In somatic symptom disorder, patients have excessive anxiety that is focused around physical symptoms.  In contrast, this patient's physical symptoms are manifestations of the severe anxiety she feels in social situations.

Educational objective:
Social anxiety disorder (SAD) is characterized by a fear of social situations and anxiety about embarrassment.  In the performance-only subtype, anxiety occurs only in performance-related situations.  SAD should be differentiated from panic disorder (unexpected panic attacks) and specific phobia (stimulus not related to social anxiety).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Social anxiety disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Social anxiety disorder.
Social anxiety disorder in DSM-5.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man comes to the office accompanied by his wife for evaluation of mood changes.  The patient's wife states that he has been restless and irritable since returning from a work trip.  While staying in a hotel 2 weeks ago, the patient was unable to leave his room on the 8th floor after an earthquake caused debris to block the door.  He had no cell phone or internet access during this time and remained in his room for 8 hours before the arrival of first responders.  His wife says he refuses to talk about the earthquake and has started sleeping in the living room to have access to multiple exit routes "in case something happens."  The patient has been working from home since he returned and is scheduled to leave for another work trip next week.  He says, "I keep waking up from nightmares, but I'm sure I'll get over this on my own.  I don't feel the need to talk about what happened because I know that getting back to my usual routine will help take my mind off of it."  On mental status examination, the patient is cooperative and provides brief responses to questions.  Although he states that his mood is "okay," he appears withdrawn.  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute stress disorder

Clinical features

  • Duration ≥3 days & ≤1 month
  • Exposure to actual or threatened trauma
  • Symptoms from following categories:
    • Avoidance of internal memories or external reminders
    • Intrusion (eg, nightmares, flashbacks)
    • Dissociation (eg, amnesia for event, derealization)
    • Arousal (eg, insomnia, hypervigilance, startle)
    • Negative mood

Management

  • Trauma-focused, brief CBT
  • Consider medication for insomnia, intense anxiety
  • Monitor for PTSD (symptom duration >1 month)

CBT = cognitive-behavioral therapy; PTSD = posttraumatic stress disorder.

This patient's presentation is suggestive of acute stress disorder (ASD), given his 2-week history of mood changes, nightmares, and hypervigilance following exposure to a traumatic event.  In addition to experiencing arousal and intrusive symptoms, patients may experience dissociation and avoidance (eg, avoidance of reminders and talking about the trauma).  Although ASD will remit in some individuals without intervention, treatment designed to alleviate symptoms and prevent development of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (diagnosed when symptoms persist for ≥4 weeks) can also be beneficial.

Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), not medication, is the first-line treatment.  However, referring for individual therapy a patient who is not ready to engage in treatment is premature and unlikely to be well received.  This patient is not seeking therapy and prefers not to talk about the trauma at this point (Choice E).  The best initial approach is to provide education on common physical and emotional responses to trauma (eg, avoidance, hypervigilance) and the course of ASD.  Normalizing the stress response, while explaining that symptoms may remit but can also cause persistent distress and impairment, would be helpful.  Recommendations for further treatment can be provided at follow-up if necessary.

(Choice A)  This patient's preference not to talk at this time should be respected.  Discussing the trauma in detail, which is typically conducted as part of trauma-focused CBT, could be undertaken when the patient is ready.

(Choice B)  This patient prefers to continue working.  Encouraging him to take a temporary leave from work would likely reinforce the patient's avoidance, potentially worsening the course of ASD.

(Choice C)  Although some patients with ASD have spontaneous resolution of symptoms, others may develop PTSD and more persistent disability.  This patient should be educated about the range of symptoms in ASD and what to do if his symptoms persist.

(Choice D)  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as paroxetine are used to treat PTSD when CBT is unavailable or if the patient prefers medication.  There is a lack of evidence for the use of SSRIs in ASD.

Educational objective:
The initial approach to patients with acute stress disorder is to educate them on the range of reactions to trauma.  Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy can be beneficial for patients with severe and persistent symptoms.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Post traumatic stress disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the patient to share his experience of the earthquake in detail
Encourage the patient to take a temporary leave from work
Provide reassurance that his symptoms will likely resolve without intervention
Review common physical and emotional responses to trauma

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The current evidence for acute stress disorder.
Immediate and early behavioral interventions for the prevention of acute and posttraumatic stress disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother due to hair loss.  The patient was cast in the lead role of the school play a month ago and has been wearing hats and wigs to stay in character.  A few days ago, her mother noticed several bald spots on the patient's scalp.  The patient does well in school and enjoys rehearsals.  She does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Menarche was at age 13; menstruation occurs every 4-6 weeks and typically lasts 5-7 days.  Vital signs are normal.  BMI is 22 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows a 3 × 5 cm area of patchy hair loss in the right parietal region surrounded by several areas of uneven hair growth.  Eyebrows are sparse.  Scalp and skin examination shows no scaling or erythema.  Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Trichotillomania (hair-pulling disorder)

Features

  • Recurrent hair pulling resulting in hair loss
  • Repeated attempts to decrease/stop hair pulling
  • Not due to a medical/dermatological condition (eg, alopecia areata)
  • Not due to another mental disorder (eg, body dysmorphic disorder)

Examination
findings

  • Irregular patches of hair loss
  • Hair shafts of variable lengths
  • Noninflammatory, nonscarring

Treatment

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (habit reversal therapy)

This patient's irregular, patchy hair loss, with areas of uneven hair and the absence of other findings, is most consistent with a diagnosis of trichotillomania, a behavioral disorder characterized by compulsive hair pulling.  Commonly affected sites include the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelids, with presentation of asymmetric, irregular areas of hair loss and/or absent eyebrows (eg, sparse eyebrows in this patient) and eyelashes.  Examination shows hairs of different lengths due to traumatic breakage at various points.  Erythema (characteristic of tinea capitis) and total hair loss (as seen in alopecia areata) are not present.

Hair pulling may be an automatic behavior (without full awareness) or preceded by tension followed by relief.  The prevalence of trichotillomania is estimated to be 1%-2% and is much more common in children and adolescent girls.  Because patients with trichotillomania feel out of control and embarrassed, they may avoid work, school, or public places and try to hide the hair loss (eg, wearing hats, wigs).  Patients who also ingest hair (trichophagia) may develop trichobezoars that can lead to abdominal pain and bowel obstruction.

(Choice A)  In alopecia areata, patches are circular, smooth, and completely devoid of hair, whereas in trichotillomania, patches are irregular, typically with broken hairs of varying lengths.

(Choice B)  Androgenetic alopecia in females (also known as female-pattern hair loss) occurs in adult women and is characterized by progressive hair thinning at the vertex and frontal hairline.

(Choice C)  Discoid lupus erythematosus, the most common form of chronic, cutaneous lupus erythematosus, is characterized by discrete, erythematous, and scaling plaques.

(Choice D)  Telogen effluvium is characterized by diffuse thinning of the hair rather than discrete patches of hair loss.  It results from premature shedding and is often triggered by stress (eg, major illness or surgery, malnutrition, emotional trauma).

(Choice E)  Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp and most commonly seen in children.  It presents with scaly, erythematous patches and alopecia, with black dots representing broken hairs within follicles.

(Choice F)  Traction alopecia is a type of hair loss resulting from prolonged tension on the hair due to hairstyles that stretch the hair (eg, braiding).  It would not explain this patient's sparse eyebrows, and hair loss in the frontal and temporal scalp is most common.

Educational objective:
Trichotillomania is a behavioral disorder characterized by recurrent hair pulling.  It results in irregular patches of hair loss with broken hair shafts of differing lengths.

Diagnosis and management of alopecia in children.

questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up regarding anxiety.  The patient was referred for treatment by the student health service due to severe anxiety accompanied by sweaty palms and shaky voice, as well as blushing when meeting new people and giving oral presentations.  He was diagnosed with social anxiety disorder and started on fluoxetine 2 weeks ago.  Today, the patient reports that his anxiety in social situations has not improved and that he has started to feel uncharacteristically tense and jittery, "like I've had too much coffee."  He says, "If anything, my anxiety is worse than before, and I feel anxious most of the time."  The patient now has difficulty falling asleep.  He has no significant medical history.  The patient does not use illicit drugs.  Vital signs are stable, and physical examination is unchanged from the initial presentation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are often a first-line treatment for depressive and anxiety disorders given their efficacy, tolerability, and general safety in overdose.  Common early adverse effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, increased anxiety, and insomnia or somnolence.  These effects usually occur in the first few weeks of treatment initiation or dose increase and diminish or resolve over time.

This patient's worsening anxiety, with jitteriness, insomnia, and new-onset anxiety in nonsocial situations, most likely reflects the stimulating effects of fluoxetine.  The mechanism may be due to SSRI-induced activation of presynaptic 5HT1A (leading to inhibition of serotonin release and a net decrease in serotonin levels) before the full effects of the medication (net increase in serotonin levels) are seen.  The most appropriate next step is a temporary dose reduction with the goal of improving tolerability; dose increases may subsequently be reattempted.

Patients with anxiety disorders are especially sensitive to the activating effects of antidepressants and should generally be started at lower doses than those typically used to treat depression (eg, half the normal starting dose), with a gradual increase to a therapeutic level over several weeks.

(Choices A, B, and F)  Compared to benzodiazepenes, buspirone (an anxiolytic that acts on the serotonergic system) is associated with a lower risk of dependence and fewer side effects but also has weaker anxiolytic effects; it is useful as augmentation therapy when anxiety is not well controlled with SSRIs.  Because this patient's increased anxiety and insomnia are most likely from fluoxetine, adding buspirone or zolpidem (a hypnotic medication used in insomnia) is not indicated, and a higher fluoxetine dose would likely exacerbate his symptoms.

(Choices D and E)  Because it may take several weeks for the full effect of an SSRI to be seen, switching to another medication after 2 weeks would be premature without first attempting dose reduction.  Bupropion is an activating antidepressant that could further increase anxiety and insomnia.  Benzodiazepines (eg, clonazepam) are not preferred as long-term monotherapy due to risks of abuse and dependence.  These drugs are sometimes prescribed adjunctively for extreme anxiety in the first weeks of treatment but should be tapered and discontinued once the antidepressant takes effect.

Educational objective:
Activating effects (eg, anxiety, insomnia) are possible early adverse effects of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors but frequently improve with time.  Patients with anxiety disorders are more sensitive to activating adverse effects and may benefit from a temporary dose reduction or initiation at a lower-than-normal dose.

questionList.title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Antidepressant efficacy and side-effect burden: a quick guide for clinicians.
Side effects of antidepressants during long-term use in a naturalistic setting.

questionList.questionText: A 57-year-old woman comes to the office with intermittent headaches, shoulder and neck pain, fatigue, and insomnia.  The headaches sometimes interfere with the patient's ability to concentrate at work.  The symptoms are not new but have worsened over the past 8 months due to the stress of starting a new job and placing her elderly mother in an assisted living facility.  The patient lies awake at night worrying about her mother, her own health problems, and the finances of her 2 adult children, who are having difficulty supporting themselves.  During the day, she is tired due to poor sleep and worries about her job performance.  The patient has a history of hypertension, irritable bowel syndrome, and tension headaches.  She drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine before bedtime a few times per week to help her relax and fall asleep.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Examination shows sweaty palms and mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness; no other abnormalities are noted.  Complete blood count, chemistry panel, TSH, urinalysis, and ECG are normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Generalized anxiety disorder

DSM-5 criteria

  • Excessive worry, anxiety (multiple issues) ≥6 months
  • Difficult to control
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms:
    • Restlessness or feeling on edge
    • Fatigue
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Sleep disturbance
  • Significant distress or impairment
  • Not due to substances, another mental disorder, or medical condition

Treatment

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • SSRI or SNRI

SNRI = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's pain, insomnia, fatigue, and poor concentration are consistent with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).  Although excessive worry about multiple issues is the key symptom in GAD, patients frequently come to their primary care provider with somatic symptoms, including fatigue and physical symptoms related to muscular tension (eg, headaches; neck, shoulder, and back pain).  Other physical manifestations of anxiety commonly seen in GAD include trembling, sweating, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

GAD typically has a lifelong, chronic course, with symptom severity increasing during periods of stress, as in this patient.  GAD is effectively treated with a serotonergic antidepressant, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), or a combination of the two.

(Choice A)  Benzodiazepines are generally reserved for patients whose GAD symptoms persist despite treatment with a serotonergic antidepressant.  These drugs are also less preferred in patients who have used alcohol to self-medicate.  Supportive psychotherapy can be helpful but is not as effective as CBT.

(Choice C)  An imaging study would be low yield in this patient, who has a known history of tension headaches, a common physical manifestation of GAD, and no focal neurological signs on examination.

(Choice D)  Pheochromocytoma may cause anxiety.  However, it is a rare disease that typically presents with paroxysmal symptoms and would not explain this patient's chronic anxiety about multiple issues.

(Choice E)  Acute intermittent porphyria can result in autonomic arousal (eg, tachycardia, hypertension, sweating) as well as anxiety, but these symptoms tend to occur in acute attacks accompanied by neuropathy (eg, weakness, numbness) and severe abdominal pain.

(Choices F and G)  Reassurance that serious medical illness has been ruled out and regularly scheduled visits are appropriate interventions for patients with somatic symptom disorder.  In contrast to the generalized worries seen in GAD, patients with somatic symptom disorder have anxiety that specifically revolves around their somatic symptoms with the fear that they have a serious medical illness.  This patient's somatic symptoms are a manifestation of GAD and should improve with effective treatment.

Educational objective:
Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive and persistent worry about multiple issues.  Patients frequently come to their primary care provider with insomnia, fatigue, and physical symptoms related to muscular tension.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Generalized anxiety disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Begin escitalopram and recommend cognitive-behavioral therapy
Obtain noncontrast CT scan of the head and neck
Obtain urinary fractionated catecholamines and metanephrines
Reassure the patient that serious medical illness has been ruled out
Schedule monthly visits to monitor symptoms

questionList.questionText:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening anxiety.  Prior to starting her new job 3 months ago, the patient had not suffered from anxiety or any other psychiatric condition.  She experiences the demands of her new job as overwhelming and disproportionate to the support and resources she has available at work.  Around the same time that she started her new job, the patient began to suffer sudden episodes of palpitations, sweating, pounding headache, and panicky feelings that have recurred every few days for no apparent reason.  The patient was also recently diagnosed with hypertension that has only slightly improved with antihypertensive medication.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 184/86 mm Hg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 14/min.  BMI is 23 kg/m2.  The patient appears anxious, mildly tremulous, and diaphoretic on examination.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin14.2 g/dL
    Platelets180,000/mm3
    Leukocytes4,100/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium3.8 mEq/L
    Chloride102 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate24 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen10 mg/dL
    Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
    Glucose190 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Pheochromocytoma

Pathogenesis

  • Arises from neuroendocrine cells in adrenal medulla
  • 25% inherited:
    • VHL gene (von Hippel-Lindau)
    • RET gene (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2)
    • NF1 gene (neurofibromatosis)
  • Symptoms result from increased catecholamine secretion

Symptoms

  • Headache
  • Tachycardia/palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Hypertension

Rule of 10s

  • 10% bilateral
  • 10% extraadrenal (paragangliomas)
  • 10% malignant

Diagnosis

Elevated urinary & plasma catecholamines & metanephrines

This patient's episodic headache, diaphoresis, tachycardia/palpitations, and anxiety symptoms in the setting of new-onset, drug-resistant hypertension and hyperglycemia with normal BMI are consistent with a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.  Signs and symptoms of pheochromocytoma are caused by catecholamine excess.  However, only 50% of patients with pheochromocytoma are symptomatic, and even in symptomatic individuals, the diagnosis is frequently missed due to the intermittent nature of symptoms.

Pheochromocytoma is most commonly diagnosed at age 30-50 and is associated with the autosomal dominant disorders of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, and neurofibromatosis type 1.  Measurements of urinary and/or plasma fractionated metanephrines and catecholamines are used to make the diagnosis.  Physicians must have a high index of suspicion for pheochromocytoma as it may be misdiagnosed as a psychiatric disorder in otherwise asymptomatic patients.

(Choice A)  Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder of heme synthesis that presents with episodic abdominal pain, tachycardia, and peripheral neuropathy.

(Choice B)  Carcinoid syndrome is most commonly associated with intestinal neuroendocrine tumors and presents with intermittent diarrhea and skin flushing; it is sometimes associated with pulmonary and/or tricuspid valvular disease.

(Choices C and F)  Patients with generalized anxiety disorder and panic disorder may have similar psychiatric and sympathetically driven somatic symptoms (eg, palpitations, diaphoresis) as those found in pheochromocytoma; however, severe, drug-resistant hypertension, hyperglycemia, and episodic pounding headache are not associated with either condition.

(Choice D)  Although hyperthyroidism may present with palpitations, diaphoresis, tremulousness, and anxiety, it is not associated with pounding headache, is not typically episodic, and is accompanied by additional signs/symptoms such as weight loss, heat intolerance, and diarrhea.

(Choice E)  An insulinoma is a pancreatic tumor that secretes insulin and is associated with episodes of hypoglycemia and resultant cognitive dysfunction, palpitations, diaphoresis, and tremor.  It is not associated with drug-resistant hypertension, hyperglycemia, or episodic headache.

Educational objective:
Pheochromocytoma is an adrenal tumor that presents with episodic headache, hypertension, tachycardia/palpitations, and diaphoresis and may be accompanied by anxiety and panic attacks.  Given the risks associated with a missed medical diagnosis, physicians must maintain a high index of suspicion for underlying medical causes of psychiatric symptoms.

questionList.questionText: A 61-year-old attorney comes to the office with his wife for follow-up.  Two months ago, the patient experienced an acute myocardial infarction while presenting a case in court and went into cardiac arrest.  He was resuscitated in the emergency department, and a drug-eluting stent was placed.  The patient recovered without complications and was discharged.  He recently returned to work part-time, although his wife thinks he needs more time to rest.  She states that he has been very stressed for the past month and worries that he is overworking.  The patient has been sleeping restlessly and frequently wakes up startled and diaphoretic.  While practicing a case presentation a few days ago, he had to stop and sit down because he felt overwhelmed.  The patient plans to "take things slowly" and has asked his partner to cover upcoming court appearances.  He has had no chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or syncope.  Medications include metoprolol, simvastatin, aspirin, and ticagrelor.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  ECG reveals no acute changes.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Posttraumatic stress disorder

Clinical
features

  • Exposure to life-threatening trauma
  • Nightmares, flashbacks, intrusive memories
  • Avoidance of reminders, dissociation
  • Emotional detachment, negative mood, decreased interest in activities
  • Sleep disturbance, hypervigilance, irritability
  • Duration >1 month

Treatment

  • Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin
reuptake inhibitors.

This patient's monthlong history of feeling stressed and overwhelmed, experiencing sleep disturbance with possible nightmares, and engaging in avoidance behavior following an acute myocardial infarction (MI) and cardiac arrest is suggestive of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Life-threatening medical events, such as acute MI, may be experienced as traumatic and result in PTSD in some patients.  Symptoms include feelings of helplessness or horror in response to the cardiac event, reexperiencing of the event (eg, intrusive thoughts, nightmares, or flashbacks of the MI, cardiac arrest, or medical procedures), psychologic distress (eg, feeling overwhelmed) and physiologic reactivity when reminded of the event, and avoidance of activities or places related to the trauma (eg, this patient avoiding returning to the courtroom, where he had a cardiac arrest).  The development of PTSD following acute MI is associated with increased risk of recurrence of cardiac events and mortality.

Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is the preferred initial treatment for PTSD.  CBT combines cognitive techniques to help correct maladaptive thoughts about the trauma and exposure-based techniques to target avoidance behaviors and help the patient process the trauma emotionally.  Pharmacotherapy with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) is an alternate option that is generally safe in patients with cardiovascular disease.

(Choice A)  The hypothetical association of beta blockers with depression has not been substantiated by rigorous studies, and there is no evidence that beta blockers exacerbate symptoms of PTSD.  In addition, beta blockers provide known survival benefit following acute MI; therefore, discontinuing metoprolol is not indicated.

(Choice B)  SSRI and SNRI antidepressants are first-line pharmacotherapy for PTSD.  Mirtazapine, a sedating antidepressant, may help with restless sleep, but it has not demonstrated efficacy in the treatment of PTSD.

(Choice C)  Echocardiography is commonly performed several months after acute MI to evaluate for a persistent reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction; however, this patient had no complications at the time of MI and has no new symptoms to suggest heart failure.

(Choice D)  Although this patient can be reassured that his cardiac condition is stable, it would be inappropriate to defer treatment of his PTSD, which causes significant distress and increases his risk for recurrent cardiovascular events.

Educational objective:
Life-threatening medical events may be experienced as traumatic and result in posttraumatic stress disorder.  Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy is the preferred initial treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Post traumatic stress disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Reassure the patient and follow up in a month

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Post-traumatic stress disorder and cardiovascular disease.
Psychological mechanisms of effective cognitive-behavioral treatments for PTSD.
Post-traumatic stress disorder among cardiac patients: prevalence, risk factors, and considerations for assessment and treatment.

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office due to "disturbing images" she has seen over the past year.  She says, "I'd be standing in the kitchen helping my mother chop vegetables, and terrible images of stabbing her in the back with a knife would pop into my head."  The patient is overwhelmed with anxiety each time this occurs, resulting in putting the knife down and running out of the kitchen.  She describes counting down from 5 to 1 several times to try to "get rid" of the thoughts, but this has not been helpful.  The patient has no medical history, and physical examination is unremarkable.  Mental status examination shows a tense and anxious affect; she becomes tearful when discussing how she would never want to hurt her mother.  She reports no depressed mood or suicidal ideation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Clinical features

  • Obsessions
    • Recurrent, intrusive, anxiety-provoking thoughts, urges, or images
  • Compulsions
    • Response to obsessions with repeated behaviors or mental acts
    • Behaviors not connected realistically with preventing feared event
  • Time-consuming (>1 hr/day) or causing significant distress or impairment

Treatment

  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (exposure & response prevention)

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is diagnosed by the presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both—with most patients having a combination.

Obsessions are characterized by involuntary, intrusive distressing thoughts, images, or urges and are managed through suppression or neutralization with a compulsion.  Compulsions are repetitive, unyielding external (eg, hand washing) or mental (eg, repeated counting) acts designed to protect against the obsession or reduce distress or anxiety.  In some cases, obsessions in OCD include unwelcome violent urges or images, as seen in this patient who has images of stabbing her mother in the back with a knife, followed by her compulsion of repeatedly counting from 5 to 1 to neutralize the thought.

First-line treatment for OCD includes exposure and response prevention (a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy) and pharmacotherapy with a serotonergic antidepressant.  All selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressants (eg, fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, fluvoxamine, citalopram, escitalopram) and the tricyclic antidepressant clomipramine are effective.  SSRIs are preferred as initial treatment due to their superior adverse-effect profile.

(Choices A and C)  Aripiprazole (a second-generation antipsychotic) and haloperidol (a first-generation antipsychotic) are not indicated as monotherapy in OCD.  Antipsychotics are sometimes used as augmentation in patients with inadequate response to SSRIs.

(Choices B and D)  Although anxiety is a prominent feature of OCD, anxiolytic medications such as buspirone and lorazepam do not treat obsessions and compulsions.  Buspirone has a role in the pharmacotherapy of generalized anxiety disorder.  Lorazepam is used in anxiety disorders and the short-term management of acute anxiety, but it carries risks of misuse and withdrawal.

Educational objective:
Treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder consists of serotonergic antidepressants and cognitive-behavioral therapy based on exposure and response prevention.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line medications.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Obsessive compulsive disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Pharmacological treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD): practical strategies for pharmacological and somatic treatment in adults.

questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by coworkers following a 15-minute episode of chest pain, shortness of breath, and sweating that started while she was giving a presentation.  She is very anxious and says, "It happened so suddenly; my heart was pounding, and I felt like I was going to pass out."  The patient first had a similar episode 3 months ago prior to giving a presentation at work and has had a number of episodes since then—while socializing with friends, before taking a flight to visit her parents, and while relaxing at home with her roommate.  Now she constantly worries about having another episode.  The patient is extremely anxious about speaking in public and has called in sick twice to avoid giving presentations, fearing that the symptoms will recur.  She has a history of a benign childhood heart murmur, asthma, and hypothyroidism.  Medications include levothyroxine and an albuterol inhaler that she uses infrequently.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Examination shows mild end-expiratory wheezing over the left lower lobe and no other abnormalities.  White blood cell count is 9,800/mm3 and TSH level is 4.2 µU/mL.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Panic disorder

Clinical
features

  • Recurrent & unexpected panic attacks with ≥4 of the following:
    • Chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, choking
    • Trembling, sweating, nausea, chills
    • Dizziness, paresthesia
    • Derealization, depersonalization
    • Fear of losing control or of dying
  • Worry about additional attacks, avoidance behavior

Treatment

  • First-line/maintenance: SSRI/SNRI &/or cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Acute distress: benzodiazepines

SNRI = serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's abrupt onset of intense episodes of anxiety accompanied by chest pain, shortness of breath, sweating, and dizziness is suggestive of panic disorder.  Diagnosis requires that at least some of these panic attacks are untriggered or unexpected (eg, at home, relaxing with friends) and the presence of ≥1 months of worry about future attacks or change in behavior (eg, avoidance).

Panic attacks may also be a symptom of other anxiety disorders; however, in these cases the panic attacks are always specifically triggered by a feared object or situation (eg, being away from home alone in agoraphobia; being in social or performance situations in social anxiety disorder) (Choices A and F).  The key difference is that in panic disorder, at least some attacks are unexpected and followed by persistent worry about future attacks.

(Choice B)  Anxiety disorder due to another medical condition is diagnosed when the panic attacks are a direct physiological consequence of another medical condition (eg, hyperthyroidism, arrhythmias, asthma).  This patient's thyroid condition is stable and her asthma attacks are infrequent and not consistently related to her panic attacks.  Her mild wheezing on examination is more likely a consequence than a cause of her panic.

(Choice C)  Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by ≥6 months of persistent worry about multiple issues and does not feature unexpected panic attacks.  Patients with panic disorder may exhibit some degree of chronic anxiety, but this is due to fears of having additional attacks, not excessive anxiety about everyday issues.

(Choice D)  Medication-induced anxiety disorder is diagnosed when panic symptoms are directly caused by exposure to a medication (eg, overmedication with albuterol or levothyroxine, precipitating panic).  However, this patient's TSH level is normal and she is using albuterol infrequently, making these unlikely causes of her recurrent attacks.

Educational objective:
Panic disorder involves recurrent unexpected panic attacks, fears of future attacks, and avoidance behavior.  Diagnosis requires differentiation from other anxiety disorders that may include triggered panic attacks and ruling out medical causes.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Panic disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Anxiety disorder due to another medical condition

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnosis and management of generalized anxiety disorder and panic disorder in adults.
A brief interview to detect panic attacks and panic disorder in emergency department patients with cardiopulmonary complaints.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man comes to the office with a 6-month history of extreme nervousness, irritability, restlessness, muscle tension, and insomnia.  He fears making mistakes in his job as an attorney and often worries that he has said something wrong.  The patient dreads the possibility of not being offered a position as a partner in the law firm despite frequent reassurance from his superiors.  As a result, he finds himself unable to concentrate or perform his duties efficiently.  The patient is also engaged and spends sleepless nights thinking about the responsibilities of married life.  He worries that he will not be a good husband or father.  The patient does not drink alcohol or use recreational substances.  He is reluctant to start psychotherapy due to his busy schedule.  Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Generalized anxiety disorder

DSM-5-TR criteria

  • Excessive worry, anxiety (multiple issues) ≥6 months
  • Difficult to control
  • 3 or more of the following symptoms:
    • Restlessness/feeling on edge
    • Fatigue
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Sleep disturbance
  • Significant distress or impairment
  • Not due to substances, another mental disorder, or medical condition

Treatment

  • First-line
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
    • SSRIs or SNRIs
  • Second-line
    • Benzodiazepines
    • Buspirone

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

This patient's 6-month history of excessive worry and anxiety, restlessness, irritability, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and sleep disturbance is consistent with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).  In GAD, the anxiety is chronic, excessive, and difficult to control; as a result, it causes significant distress or impairment.

Treatment of GAD includes cognitive-behavioral therapy, medication, or a combination of both.  Preferred initial medications for GAD include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) such as venlafaxine.  No antidepressant has been shown to be a superior treatment, so medication selection is based on the adverse effect profile and the patient's treatment history.  SSRIs/SNRIs are also effective in treating depression, a common comorbidity.

Benzodiazepines (eg, diazepam, lorazepam) are effective but considered second-line treatments due to the risks for misuse, dependence, and tolerance and the potential for withdrawal syndromes and rebound effects with abrupt discontinuation (Choices B and C).  Benzodiazepines can be used when antidepressants are ineffective or poorly tolerated but should be avoided in patients with a history of substance use or significant comorbid depression.  They can also be used as an adjunct to manage acute anxiety while waiting for SSRIs or SNRIs to take effect.

Buspirone, a nonbenzodiazepine anxiolytic, has been used to treat GAD in patients without comorbid depression or panic symptoms.  Although it has a slower onset of action and weaker anxiolytic effects than benzodiazepines, it can be helpful in patients with a high risk for benzodiazepine misuse.

(Choice A)  Bupropion is a norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor that is sometimes used off-label in the management of GAD; however, it has greater potential for more severe adverse effects (eg, worsened anxiety, increased restlessness) compared to preferred first-line serotonergic agents.

(Choice D)  The beta blocker propranolol is an effective treatment of the performance subtype of social anxiety disorder, but it is not used in the treatment of GAD.

(Choice E)  Second-generation antipsychotics, such as quetiapine, should not be used as first-line treatment for GAD.  They are sometimes prescribed when a patient's condition is resistant to treatment, but they have significant adverse effects (eg, sedation, metabolic effects).

(Choice G)  Zolpidem is a sedative-hypnotic medication that could target this patient's insomnia but would not address his other GAD symptoms.

Educational objective:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (eg, venlafaxine) are first-line medication options for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Generalized anxiety disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Comparative remission rates and tolerability of drugs for generalised anxiety disorder: a systematic review and network meta-analysis of double-blind randomized controlled trials.

questionList.questionText: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office due to poor sleep for the past 2 months.  The patient says, "Most nights, I wake up around 2 AM in a state of panic—my heart is racing and it's hard to fall back asleep.  I can barely stay awake at work, and it takes me twice as long to finish assignments because I need to reread everything."  The patient lives alone and works as a computer programmer.  She filed for divorce 3 months ago due to her husband's substance use and violent behavior toward her.  The patient drinks a glass of wine at bedtime to help her fall asleep and does not use illicit drugs.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are unremarkable.  On mental status examination, she appears tired and her mood is depressed and anxious.  The patient jumps when a nearby door slams closed.  At one point, she appears to stare into space and does not respond to her name for a few moments.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Posttraumatic stress disorder

Clinical
features

  • Exposure to life-threatening trauma
  • Nightmares, flashbacks, intrusive memories
  • Avoidance of reminders, dissociation
  • Emotional detachment, negative mood, decreased interest in activities
  • Sleep disturbance, hypervigilance, irritability
  • Duration >1 month

Treatment

  • Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin
reuptake inhibitors.

This patient with a history of exposure to intimate partner violence has several features suggestive of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), including sleep disturbance (poor sleep, panicked awakening), dissociation (eg, momentarily staring and unresponsive), negative mood, and hypervigilance/increased startle response (eg, when nearby door slams).  Other characteristic features of PTSD include flashbacks, intrusive memories, and avoidance of reminders of the traumatic event.

Patients with PTSD commonly experience depressed mood, irritability, and anxiety and frequently have classic mood symptoms such as insomnia, fatigue, and impaired concentration.  Patients may be reluctant to disclose trauma, so physicians must remain alert to signs and symptoms of PTSD and provide further assessment and treatment.  Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy and antidepressants are first-line treatments.

(Choice A)  Adjustment disorder develops within 3 months of an identifiable stressor and causes significant distress.  However, it is not diagnosed when the stressor is of a traumatic nature (rather than a common occurrence) and when the patient has a constellation of symptoms (eg, dissociation, hypervigilance) suggestive of a more specific disorder (eg, PTSD).

(Choice B)  Depersonalization/derealization (ie, feeling detached from one's body, experiencing surroundings as unreal) is considered part of PTSD and is not diagnosed as a separate disorder when PTSD is present.  The specifier, "with dissociative symptoms," can be added to the PTSD diagnosis when such symptoms are persistent.

(Choice C)  Although generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is also characterized by anxiety, sleep disturbance, and impaired concentration, these patients worry about a multitude of everyday events.  In addition, a duration of 6 months is required for diagnosis of GAD.

(Choice D)  Major depressive disorder would not explain this patient's panicked awakening, heightened startle response, or dissociation.  Negative mood states, decreased interest in activities, and emotional detachment are common features of PTSD.

(Choice E)  Patients with panic disorder experience unprovoked panic attacks at any time during the day or night.  This patient's nighttime panic symptoms are more likely due to nightmares related to PTSD.

Educational objective:
Patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) commonly have symptoms of sleep disturbance, impaired concentration, and negative mood.  A history of trauma, dissociative symptoms, and increased startle response are clues for PTSD.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man with no significant medical history comes to the office with concerns about recurrent episodes of sudden heart pounding, shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, shaking, and tingling in his extremities over the past several months.  The episodes last about 10 minutes and are associated with feelings of unreality and detachment from his body.  The patient fears having episodes while at work or driving and worries that he may have a heart condition or a serious undiagnosed disease.  He has seen other physicians, who performed extensive medical workups but found nothing wrong.  His worry has progressively worsened, and he now feels anxious all the time.  The patient does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Routine laboratory testing, ECG, and physical examination show no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Panic disorder

Clinical
features

  • Recurrent & unexpected panic attacks with ≥4 of the following:
    • Chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, choking
    • Trembling, sweating, nausea, chills
    • Dizziness, paresthesia
    • Derealization, depersonalization
    • Fear of losing control or of dying
  • Worry about additional attacks, avoidance behavior

Treatment

  • First-line/maintenance: SSRI/SNRI &/or cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Acute distress: benzodiazepines

SNRI = serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

The unexpected and abrupt onset of symptoms in this otherwise healthy patient with repeated negative medical workups is suggestive of panic disorder.  Patients with panic disorder frequently have cardiorespiratory symptoms and may fear they are having a heart attack and repeatedly seek medical care.  Other symptoms may include gastrointestinal distress, paresthesias, and dissociative symptoms such as derealization and depersonalization.  Patients typically develop anticipatory anxiety about subsequent attacks and may develop chronic anxiety.  They may reasonably become preoccupied with their symptoms and fears of having an undiagnosed condition, making it difficult to differentiate panic disorder from a somatic symptom disorder.

(Choice A)  Conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) involves development of a neurological symptom that is inconsistent with recognized neurological disease.

(Choice B)  This patient's feelings of derealization and depersonalization are associated symptoms of his panic attacks.  Depersonalization/derealization disorder should not be diagnosed when the symptoms occur only during panic attacks that are part of panic disorder.

(Choice C)  In factitious disorder, patients intentionally falsify symptoms in order to assume the sick role.

(Choice D)  This patient has become chronically anxious because he fears recurrent panic attacks.  His anxiety is restricted to fears surrounding his panic symptoms, and he does not have the excessive worries about multiple issues required for a diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder.

(Choice E)  In illness anxiety disorder, patients experience excessive anxiety about having or acquiring a serious illness and have few or no somatic symptoms.  This patient has multiple somatic symptoms, and he is concerned that they are due to a medical illness because he has not yet been accurately diagnosed.  Illness anxiety disorder is not diagnosed when the illness-related preoccupation is better explained by another mental disorder, such as panic disorder.

(Choice G)  Multiple physical symptoms, high health care use, and a preoccupation with symptoms are seen in both panic disorder and somatic symptom disorder.  However, in somatic symptom disorder, physical symptoms are persistent over time.  This patient's acute physical symptoms are characteristic of panic disorder and do not persist between panic attacks.

Educational objective:
Patients with panic disorder may be misdiagnosed with a somatic symptom disorder due to preoccupation with unexplained symptoms and a history of high health care use.  The recurrent abrupt onset of characteristic physical symptoms that resolve within minutes should raise clinical suspicion for panic disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of an 8-month history of anxiety, nightmares, and flashbacks after returning from a military deployment.  She has been taking sertraline for the past 6 months and completed a course of cognitive-behavioral therapy recently.  The patient reports her symptoms have mostly improved, and she no longer has intrusive thoughts or flashbacks related to her time in a combat zone.  She says, "My mood feels lighter, and I've started spending more time with friends and family.  I can't seem to sleep through the night though.  I'm still having scary dreams about my time in the army."  She drinks a glass of wine twice a week and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs.  Medical history is noncontributory.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Posttraumatic stress disorder

DSM-5

  • Exposure to life-threatening trauma
  • Intrusion symptoms: nightmares, flashbacks
  • Avoidance symptoms: avoids distressing thoughts, feelings & external reminders of the event
  • Negative mood & cognitions: persistent horror, anger, guilt, negative beliefs about self & the world, decreased interest in activities, emotional detachment, amnesia for event
  • Arousal symptoms: sleep disturbance, hypervigilance, impaired concentration
  • Duration: more than 1 month

Treatment

  • Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)
  • Prazosin for nightmares

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

First-line treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) includes trauma-focused cognitive behavioral psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI).  This patient's symptoms of PTSD have improved with psychotherapy and sertraline, but she continues to experience distressing nightmares.

Meta-analyses have shown that prazosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist, is effective for treatment of PTSD-related nightmares and is particularly helpful as an adjunct to SSRI or SNRI treatment.  Prazosin is thought to reduce nightmare frequency by decreasing the adrenergic hyperactivity found in many patients with PTSD.  Prazosin is administered at bedtime and requires titration to reduce the risk of effects on blood pressure (eg, orthostasis).

(Choice A)  Benzodiazepines (eg, clonazepam) are not effective in the treatment of PTSD-related nightmares and carry risks of addiction and dependence.  They should particularly be avoided in patients with an active substance use disorder.

(Choice B)  There is no evidence that psychodynamic psychotherapy can effectively target PTSD-related nightmares.  Exposure-based cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is the therapy of choice for PTSD; CBT techniques to target nightmares specifically include image rehearsal therapy, in which nightmares are rewritten with a positive outcome.

(Choice D)  This patient's PTSD symptoms have improved significantly on sertraline.  There is no evidence that paroxetine is more effective in treating nightmares than other SSRIs, and switching antidepressants could risk worsening other PTSD symptoms.

(Choice E)  This patient is benefiting from sertraline, and tapering risks relapse.

Educational objective:
Prazosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist, is effective for the treatment of posttraumatic stress disorder–related nightmares.  It is particularly helpful as an adjunct to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor or serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor treatment.
